The problem is of the "unintended consequences".  By changing the course of this one asteroid, we have no idea as to the potential impact this could create further down the path. We do not know if one of these potential impact could then cascade and create a much bigger disaster down the road. It has taken billions of years of impacts to clear most of the potential asteroids impacts on Earth. By this one move, we could potentially disrupt this process and endanger the Earth. If the attempt was a test to steer the said asteroid onto a path that would force a direct impact with the Sun, that would be a much safer plan than to just simply redirect its path.

Since they don't truly know the exact composition of this little 557 foot moonlet, they cannot truly be sure of its mass beforehand.  If it was formed by rotational ejections of Didymos as speculated, it's basically very light, but if it was a capture by a heavier than guessed at Didymos, then the composition of Dimorphos, could be much different.  So knowing the velocity and mass of the impact device means they'll be able to infer its true weight by observing the effects afterwards.  It'll be interesting to see how correct their assumptions were after the fact.
